issues.description: The PersonResource constructor signatures differ between the template and the solution. The template defines a single-argument constructor taking only PersonService (public PersonResource(PersonService personService) { ... }), while the solution defines a two-argument constructor (public PersonResource(PersonService personService, String apiKey) { ... }). This is a structural mismatch (constructor parameter difference) that can confuse students about the expected wiring and may cause autowiring failures or uncertainty about how to obtain/configure the additional String dependency in the solution code. Because the problem statement and template do not mention an apiKey or any extra constructor parameter, the additional String parameter in the solution appears unintended and inconsistent with the provided starter code and specification.

The PersonResource constructor has different parameter lists in the template and the solution. The template defines PersonResource(PersonService personService) while the solution defines PersonResource(PersonService personService, String apiKey). This introduces an unexpected identifier (apiKey) in the solution that is not present or described in the problem statement or the template. Students comparing template → problem → solution may be confused about what apiKey represents, why it is required, and where that String bean/value comes from. The mismatch adds unnecessary cognitive load when mapping the problem's described "PersonResource" concept to the provided and final implementations.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor signatures consistent. Either remove the additional String apiKey parameter from the solution's PersonResource constructor so it matches the template and the problem description, or add the same parameter (with documentation) to the template and the problem statement and ensure a corresponding bean/value is provided. Prefer removing the extra parameter in the solution unless there is a documented reason for apiKey to exist.
